DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Say Bring Combat Troops Back Soon; Police Work Could Last
Eds: ADDS 3 grafs to UPDATE with Obey comment on need for new elections in Panama.
With AM-US-Panama Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American combat soldiers should be withdrawn from Panama as quickly as possible, members of Congress said Thursday, but one said some troops should remain as policemen and could still be there ``on Christmas eve a year from now.'' Rep. Les. Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said the presence of U.S. soldiers may be required for an indefinite period if the Panamanian Defense Forces are unable to perform normal police functions and defend the new democratic government. ``I think the chances are that there is going to be a need for them to be there,'' Aspin said, adding that police and public safety operations in Panama appeared to have broken down. Manuel Antonio Noriega's Panamanian Defense Forces performed many police functions as well as military ones. Their headquarters was the main target of the first U.S. assault. Aspin said of some U.S. troops: ``I do see a need for them to stay. I would not be surprised to see them there on Christmas eve a year from now.'' He said that American combat troops were withdrawn from Grenada two months after the U.S. intervention there but that military police units were not removed until 18 months later. Other members of Congress said there is a pressing need to move far faster in Panama. Rep. Frank McCloskey, D-Ind., a member of the House Armed Services Committee, said ``the most negative situation'' would exist if in 24 hours Noriega _ now a fugitive with a $1 million reward offered for his capture _ was holding hostages, or if fighting lasted beyond 24 to 48 hours. ``I'd say if we have any kind of significant ongoing hostilities or ongoing hostage situation where Noriega has some leverage, it's going to be an extremely tense time for the Americans,'' he said. Aspin agreed that a combination of an uncaptured Noriega, a faltering government, attacks on Americans and sporadic sniper fire could change positive perceptions of the U.S. action. ``You could have this thing turn real sour for George Bush real quick,'' Aspin said. McCloskey said, ``I backed President Bush and the necessity to make a military move on Noriega, given the violence against our own military personnel and dependents. As in any situation things go wrong in the implementation. ``I just hope they are supersensitive to concerns for civilian casualties, both Americans and Panamanians,'' McCloskey said. Rep. Nicholas Mavroules, D-Mass, another committee member, said there are several positive aspects in the present situation in Panama. ``Noriega is not administering the affairs of the government of Panama, that is the key factor,'' he said. ``I think Noriega's input into the affairs of Panama is at an end.'' ``If we can firm up the new government, make that government secure, then the special forces have to come out of there,'' Mavroules said. He said that if U.S. forces remain _ and their stay is seen as long-term or indefinite _ the governments of Latin America would be ``extremely upset to see any American military outside of the U.S. bases.'' ``That's why it's important they get out, and that they get out just as quickly, just as soon as possible,'' Mavroules said. ``But I can't place any time limit on that,'' the congressman said. Much congressional comment has been supportive of Bush's action in sending thousands of troops against Noriega and his forces. However, there has been criticism, too. Rep. Pat Schroeder, D-Colo., said, ``As much as we support Tuesday's U.S. military action in Panama, we should remember ... that Noriega himself is the toxic waste of a polluted Reagan-Bush foreign policy.'' ``Noriega was A-OK as long as he did our bidding and supported assistance to the Contras in Nicaragua,'' she said. ``It didn't matter if he murdered Panamanians or peddled cocaine.'' Meanwhile, the chairman of a subcommittee that controls foreign aid said the new government should call elections to revalidate its popular support in the face of criticism that it is a U.S.-installed regime. ``The new Panamanian government ... will have difficulty establishing credibility throughout Latin America unless it immediately announces that it regards itself as a temporary government and will guarantee a new election next year,'' Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., said in a letter to Bush. Elections would mute criticism and ``could create a much more stable situation in Panama than would otherwise be the case,'' said Obey, chairman of the House Appropriations foreign operations subcommittee.
